column1: Zagazig (Arabic: الزقازيق‎ az-Zaqāzīq  Egyptian Arabic pronunciation: [ez.zæʔæˈziːʔ]
column2: rural: [ez.zæɡæˈziːɡ]) is a city in Lower Egypt. Situated in the eastern part of the Nile delta
column3: it is the capital of the governorate of Sharqia.

column1: It is located on the Muweis Canal and is a hub of the corn and cotton trade. There is a museum of antiquities
column2: the Sharkeya National Museum (sometimes called the Amed Orabi Museum
column3: at Herriat Raznah) that contains many important archaeological exhibits (currently closed for restoration).Zagazig University
column4: one of the largest universities in Egypt
column5: is also located in the city
column6: with colleges in different fields of science and arts. The Archaeological Museum of the University of Zagazig exhibits significant finds from the nearby sites
column7: Bubastis (Tell Basta) and Kufur Nigm. Also there is a branch for Al-Azhar University
column8: the largest Islamic university in the world.

column1: Zagazig is the birthplace of famous Coptic Egyptian journalist
The most notable streets in Zagazig are Farouk Street

The city was found in the 19th century on a place of a village called Nazlat az-Zaqāzīq which was named after the Zaqzuq family. The family's name itself comes form a dialectal word zaqzuq or ziqziq which means "a small creature" (e.g. a fish or a mouse) and comes from a Coptic word ϫⲉⲕϫⲓⲕ "ant or other insect".The ruins of the ancient Egyptian city of Bubastis are located 3 kilometres (1.9 mi) southeast of town. Bubastis was the ancient capital of the 18th nome
column2: and is home to the feast celebrating the cat goddess Bastet.

column1: Bubastis is the Greek version of the Egyptian language name Pr-Bastet "House [Temple] of Bastet". Bubastis became the capital of Egypt in the 22nd and 23rd Dynasties. There are remains of the temples built by Osorkon II and Nectanebo II. Catacombs where the sacred cats were buried are located behind an Old Kingdom chapel remains that are from the period of Pepi I Meryre.
Köppen-Geiger climate classification system classifies its climate as hot desert (BWh)

column2: the largest family in Sharqia and Egypt's largest Circassian community.
colonel who led the revolt against the British in 1882
